FacilityName: ELKTON FARMERS UNION COOP OIL ASS'N

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan Executive Summary
Facility: Elkton Farmers Union Coop Oil Ass'n
Contact:  Ivan Vomacka
Phone:  (605) 542-7771
1.  Facility Policy
     The owners, management and employees of the Elkton Farmers Union Coop Oil Ass'n are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If any accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Elkton Fire Dept., Brookings County LEPC and or other authorities to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the environment.
2. Facility information:
    The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a nutrient for crop production.  The maximum quanity stored would be 200,000 pounds in a storage tank and the nurse tanks.
3.  Worse case senario and alternate release senario
     A.  The worst case senario would be the release of the entire contents of the storage tank released as a gas over the period of ten minutes.  The maximum quanity released would be 130,000 pounds, which represents the volume of the only storage tank at the 85% volume level as allowed by design standards and administrative controls.  The distance to the end point (point of dispersion to 200 parts per million) is 4.4 miles.
     B.  The alternate release senario: a three inch transfer hose is used as as alternate release senario followed by the release on ammonia for two minutes before the automatic excess flow shut-down valve intervenes and stops the flow of gas.  The maximum quanity released would be 28,000 pounds.  The distance to the end point is .7 miles.  ( The most likely potential accident would be a release from a break in a one inch transfer hose scenario followed by a release of ammonia for 2 minutes before the automatic excess flow shut-down valve intervened and stopped the flow of ammonia.  The maximum quanity released with this senario would b

e 2901 pounds.  The distance to the end point is .3 miles.
4.  Accidental release prevention program:
     The facility is in compliance with the provisions of the standards of the U. S. Occupational and Health Administration(OSHA), 29 CFR 1910,111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  The OSHA standard is referenced in the RMP registration form, see section 8.3 (b)
5.  Five year accident history.
     The facility has had no accidental released of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused and deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility, nor, to our knowledge, has there been and accidental releases resulting in any off-site deaths, injuries, significant property damage, evacuations or environmental damage.
6.  Emergency Action Plan
     The facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard 29CFR 1910.38;  Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and right to know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)
7.  Planned changes to provide safety
     Safety is monitored at this facility in an on-going process.  Periodic evaluations are performed and assesed to determine if any changes or updates need to be made to improve safety.  There are no additional specific recommendations regarding safety at this time to do with the receiveing, storage, transfer, or delivery of anhydrous ammonia.
